text: We are recording.
Thank you and good morning to the May 25th, 2021 meeting.
It is 9:32 A.M.
I'm Lisa Herbold.
Chair of the committee.
Chair Gonzcez informed my office she would not be in attendance and we have chair Pedersen acting as alternate.
If you can please call rule.
Councilmember Lewis.
Present.
Councilmember Morales.
Here.
Councilmember Sawant.
Present.
Councilmember Pedersen.
Here.
Chair Herbold.
Five present.
Thank you so much.
On today's agenda, we will be hearing the office of police accountability's 2020 annual report, hearing from Andrew Myerberg and Anne Bettesworth.
Just want to start with some chair's remarks on the one-year anniversary of the murder of George Floyd by Minneapolis police officers.

Reflecting on this day, I came across a column written by K Cummings on the Seattle times risk of the pendulum of support for the black lives matter movement leaning toward the status quo based on the history of that occurring when past generations have called for justice from lack Americans.
Cummings said "like freedom, selfishness is a foundation stone of the American experience.
Our history is one long pattern of certain people satisfying their selfish needs at the expense of a selected few beginning with the indigenous peoples and the exploitation of enslaved Africans.
We quickly learned racial justice in America arrives and recedes like a pendulum toward justice for a time and then back again towards Selfishnes."
Last summer we asked the court to maintain a consent decree in the face of police response and mostly peaceful protests.

Now we are faced with a consent decree that is a barrier to passage of policy, regulating the use of weapons like blast balls and tear gas and a consent decree that is a barrier as well to the Council for billing our commitment to reduce the police Department's budget and to hold them accountable for unauthorized overtime spending beyond the budget granted by the Council and using those funds for other pressing needs.
Just a few words about the blanket bill because we did not hear it in full counsel today.
The budget bill may be one such example of that swing of the pendulum.
And the risk of our efforts to work to increase funding for alternatives to policing and increase the number of things that we asked the police Department to do.
The bill that we have discussed in committee has been intended to be a compromise that sticks to our commitment to hold SPD accountable for excessive overtime spending to police protests.
It includes $3 million in reduction in SPD spending and it is opposed by some on the Council because it is not the full 5.4 million and opposed by others because it is any cut at all.
This despite the fact that SPD will have 13 million in salary savings available in the 2021 budget.
To me, this is an example of a way to find ways to Reallocate funds from the SPD budget toward other public safety investments.
And I worry that it signals Úthat the pendulum is swinging back to the status quo and away from the unity that the Council has had over the last year on our efforts.

Another example, yesterday was the temporary, hopefully, unraveling of the Council's unified position from the fall on moving the SPD parking enforcement officers into the new community safety and communication center.
In support of the Peo100 worker workforce vision of community safety and mostly in response to lobbying.
We also were asked last summer to withdrawal the city's lawsuit posing King County's new inquest process and the city was engaged in opposing new process.
And today we are waiting for answers.
We want to recognize our accomplishment over the last year and be allocated $30 million from the budgeting process and inform future policy making and making investments to build community safety.
We invested $4 million to launch the Seattle community safety initiative with three community safety hubs and Wraparound services in the central district, South East and West Seattle.

We have invested 12 million to build the capacity of Community- based organizations working to build safety from the ground up in our neighborhoods including violence--ending violence and reducing crime.
We move the advocacy team for crisis response to the human services Department.
We have restored a million dollars to the office of civil rights for grants for organizations fulfilling alternatives to or addressing harm created by the criminal legal system.
We have talked to mental health professionals on the SPD response in the Department.
And respond to health crises.

We also invested in million door dollars to expand neighborhood based teams of medical health and substance abuse and professionals to respond to individuals expensing chronic or behavioral issues and people experiencing unsheltered homelessness and we have funded a restorative justice pilot program in the Seattle public schools.
We passed the youth rights ordinance named after a teenager who in 2017 was shot and killed by plain clothing deputies during a misguided sting operation that were only targeted two teenagers.
We added a crisis counselor to the Seattle fire Department and increased interactions with people in crisis.
We were requiring with the new law that Seattle police officers give badges and badge numbers . We have expanded health one to create three new response teams.
Two of them knew, for firefighters and police officers to respond to more 911 calls.
The Council created community safety and medication center which just yesterday . It was a big step forward in Recalibrating our efforts to not require sworn officers to respond.
We reached an agreement for the first time in the police Commission to have a formal role in police Union contract negotiations.

And we reduced our reliance on Incarceration by redirecting $8 million from this year and next in the King County jail contract, community based and health program to promote upstream safety and health.
We removed outdated drug laws from the Seattle municipal code recommended by the Reentry Workgroup.
And in addition, a number of Council members advocated at the state Legislature for changes at the state law in pursuit of greater accountability measures.

The Council took these votes that were made possible by the voices and sustained action of thousands of protesters that made it clear that day after day in the middle of the pandemic no less that community safety cannot be achieved with the restructuring of our response crisis calls and Non- police alternatives to people in crisis.
You flung the city's pendulum toward justice.
And when I say you, I mean everyone in Healthcare who has been doing this work.
I know these changes are your effort and this work is not done.
Closing, I just want to say before we move to public comment, that it is appropriate that on this day we hear from our office of police accountability about their work over the past year.
And Andrew Myerberg says changes are needed to keep improving the systems both locally and statewide.
Hearing his report, together with the recommendations of the office of the inspector general and the community police Commission, it is all part of improving an imperfect system of accountability.
We want to honor the life of George Lloyd this morning and also recognize the depths Derek Hayden and others at the hands of Seattle police officers over the last year.
I want to take a pause.
I have received (Indiscernible) and receiving some opening remarks, counsel callings if you folks have points that you would like to add.
You are certainly encouraged to do so.
Otherwise, I will move into approval.
Councilmember Sawant.
Thank you chair Herbold.
I appreciate the chance to make some opening remarks and not interrupt the presentation at different times.
And because my questions are more Overarching on specific slide items.
I would like to quickly Frontload those questions as well.

As I'm sure everyone who is watching would know, my office is completely convinced that the Seattle police accountability system, as we have it, is fundamentally broken on a structural level and as far as any individual decision made in the office of police accountability, although I have a substantial disagreement with those decisions.

The point is that the Overarching context, and I want to be crystal clear about the Overarching context because otherwise the points that come from the office, and some of them I lay out right now, but why the police were not held accountable for the mass brutality of the black lives matter movement last summer will be lost in second- degree details Unfortunately, this has happened repeatedly from Presenters where the Overarching context of the failure and police accountability is not kept in context.
We need elected oversight board with full powers over the police de to--to higher--hire and fire police officers and carry out investigations.
Director Andrew Myerberg and others are not sworn officers.
They are not independent of the Mayor and the overall political establishment.
It is not just about the individual police officers.
All of those are crucial components.
But this is not in the vacuum of the overall establishment that has failed in its task on police accountability.
The Mayor ordered the police to guess the people of Seattle last summer, in addition to using other weaponry, so-called less lethal weapons, on peaceful protesters repeatedly night after night.
So how can they be excited to hold the police accountable after that overwhelming police violence.
And the police contract that I was Unfortunately the only representative on the Council to vote against, effectively creates a 180 statute of limitations on police being held accountable.
Does that mean all of the investigations into the police violence are effectively over?
You did not sustain the thousands of complaints against the officers--against the officer that pepper sprayed a child in the face.
How can you justify that?
I have asked this question in the committee before and have not had any kind of satisfactory answers.
The response has been that it is regrettable but consistent with these procedures.
This is a response we have had from director Andrew Myerberg and others.
We respond when our office vote for legislation putting a ban on the police from using these chemical weapons against protesters.
You opposed to that.
So you say it is regrettable but it is simply not credible when you oppose every effort to stop it.
You exonerate the police officer saying that the officer acted within the law and then you opposed changing the law.
Why do you think the police are so confident that they can Brutalize black lives matter protesters without consequence?
Do you think the Seattle police were generally held accountable for the violence they unleashed on our community during the black lives matter movement last summer?
These are my questions.
I hope that today will be different and we will have different answers and on this statute of limitations.

Unfortunately, I'm not very hopeful but I did want to register those questions because I think it is extremely important for us as elected representatives to continue pushing on things, even though we have not had results yet.
Thank you so much.
Thank you Councilmember Sawant . seeing no other hands, I will move to approval of the agenda.
The agenda will be adopted.
Hearing no objection, it is adopted.
At this time, we will transition into public comment.
I will moderate the public comment period in the following manner.
Each Speaker will be given minutes to speak.
We will call in each Speaker by name and the order for which they registered on the Council Website.
If you have not registered to speak what you would like to do so, you can sign up for the end of the public hearing at the end of the comment period by going to the Council's Website.
A link is also listed on today's agenda.
When I call a Speaker's name, you will hear a prompt and when you hear a prompt, you need to press Star six and Unmute yourself.
You can begin by stating your name and the item you are seeing on the agenda.
You will hear a time when 10 seconds are left.
We ask that you then wrap up your public comment.
Speakers cannot end the, said the end of the allotted minutes provided.
The Speaker microphone will be muted after 10 seconds.
When you have completed your public comment, please Disconnect from the line.
And if you can, please follow the meeting using the Seattle panel or the listening options on the agenda.
Right now, it looks like we have 10 people signed up for public comment.
And I will call on the first few speakers.
Let me get over to my Sign-Up sheet.
We first have Howard Gail.
Good morning.
Howard Dale, District seven.
Today is the one-year anniversary of George White's death, a day when our are zone hearts and eyes were open to the extent and brutality of police abuse.
Today, the OPA director Andrew Myerberg will go behind and blind us and harden our hearts with numbers and lies.

This will be done by a man who spent his entire professional career, 13 years, defending police including defending the New York City police against illegal and righteous claims of the central park five.
You are the only numbers that matter today.
The numbers the directors here to obscure.
Those are the days that Terry Cavers murder went unnoticed with Andrew Myerberg claiming there were no complaints by OPA despite the fact that I did make a complaint.
371 for the days that we are still waiting for the OPA report on the SPD murder of Terry Cavers.
27 for the number of people killed by a speedy in the first decade of the century before John Williams.
29 for the number of people killed by a speedy in the last decade after John Williams and the start of the police reform process.
By the way, 29 is bigger than 27.
All these killings are ruled lawful and proper were never investigated or they are still Waitng for the investigation to be completed.
One is a number of SP officers with anything more than a Reprimand for all of the abuse and harm unleashed on hundreds over the last 12 months.
Two is a number of days suspension with or without pay.
Suggested as discipline for the one single officer receiving more than a Reprimand.
Nine is the number of years we have pretended to have police Acountability.
There are many Heart-Wrenching stories buried in the numbers that Myerberg will put before you today to stands out.
Last July when an Sp officer intentionally threw a blessed ball at Rence rocky, the same month, over a dozen officers stood passively over Samantha six as she suffered epileptic seizures.
In both these cases, Myerberg ruled the abuse complaints were not sustained.
We need to have civilian oversight.
I invite everyone to join us at Seattlestop.Org.
Thank you, Howard.

You hear me?
We can.
Great.
Hello Seattle city council.
I'm a resident and District and medical researcher in Seattle.
I'm here representing the organization, Decriminalize Seattle.
In the wake of this position, many lawmakers on the state level are wary of pursuing recent laws drugs laws is another Regressive continuation.

The city of Seattle Actonel and passes a resolution Decriminalizing and protecting medical practitioners who prescribe them and can demonstrate there is still public appetite for change in the status quo.
A similar nine was--similar law was voted on and passed by double digits in the overwhelming demographic similar situation.
This is incredible for a popular issue.
The organization has won the Endorsements of many medical practitioners, indigenous Healers and all the local legislative district within the city of Seattle we have spoke with.
Personally I think the streets substance abuse, depression, Ptsd and in some parallel relative to pharmaceutical medicine.
The city of Seattle should join a dozen other Misle bodies such as Washington D.C., Oakland, and Denver in passing this reform.
Thank you.
Thank you so much.
Next Speaker is Ben Holcomb followed by Lila burns.
Hello.
My name is Ben Holcomb and I'm a resident in district three and I'm speaking on the criminal nature Seattle.
And hope you will adopt the equalization of Psychedelics in Seattle.
I would like to talk to you about my own expense with Psychedelics and how they relate to broader studies of Psychedelics across the country.
My first time taking it was over a decade ago.
Experience mostly a sense of peace is with myself and the world.
I came out of the trip with a confidence in myself that made me a genuinely happier person.
There have been multiple studies that have shown that over 66% of patients receiving Psychedelic treatment, regard the session is the most spiritual expanse of their lives.
You have heard from me and other volunteers that these have healed anxiety.
My question to you, city hall, is why would we want to continue Incarcerating people for continuing to better themselves.
Like it looks have shown to have incredible medical benefits.
Would any of you say the same about alcohol or tobacco?
I'm asking you to take a look at the facts and testimonials we have given before you and ask yourselves how keeping these substances Criminalized benefits anyone.
We cannot let Seattle get left behind practicing archaic drug laws that have proven to not work.
It is an equitable and safe access just like so many cities have done before us.
We can do better, Seattle.
Support our resolution.
I yield my time.
Next Speaker is Lila burns.
Hello.
Can you hear me?
Calling regarding counsel bill one 1981 which gives money to a speedy that should go to Participatory budgeting.
After you committed to defending last summer.
I urge Council to reject the bill and follow through with Defunding a speedy.
Today marks one year since murder of George Floyd.
The was police have killed at least 1060 people ever since.
414 just in 2021 including Seattle police who killed both Gregory Taylor and Derek Hayden in the span of a single week.
Police do not make us safer.
Spd does not need more money.
The OPA findings can be Overruled by the police chief and the consent decree claims to be an oversight body but it has been used to evade the Teargas ban last summer and delay this bill for months.
Black lives matter is directly putting danger into this bill.
The conviction of Derek Chauvin s not justice.
It is one rare form of police accountability that was achieved through immense pressure.
Seattle city Council has power over the SPD budget and must use it to intervene and the continued killing and Brutalization of your constituents.
Honor George Floyd and consider the commitments to the black lives you have made or broken in the years since his murder.
It has been one year and the demands of the protest have not been met.
We want to Defund SP by 50% at least.
Reallocate the funds to by committees.
Release all protesters without charges.
For no new you still.
And Jenny Durkan resigned.
Please reject the counsel bill bill when it goes to full counsel . I yield my time.
Valerie Florez.
Good morning.
I live in beacon Hill.
On today's agenda is the presentation of the OPA's annual report.
I have read it.
It reveals the Pro- police bias baked into the Star current system police accountability.
There are multiple points where the report language Associates protest after the murder of George Floyd with complaints to the OPA, as if protest was the cause of complaint.
Let's be clear.
Protest is the exercise of the constitutional right to freedom of speech.
It is possible to have protest without the police response of escalation, retaliation and a--an attack on civilians that we saw last summer.
Those actions by SPD were clearly unnecessary.
That was documented in many videos.
Protests are not a reason for people filing complaints to the OPA.
The abusive behavior of SPD and response to protest is the reason for the complaint.
How SPD handles protests and how it polices it at other times are obviously related.
The problems with policing in our city take a high toll year after year.
That is an ongoing problem that is obscured in the annual report that the OPA is presenting today.
The report gives some Metrics without giving real information about complaints or consequences.
At several points, the OPA says it increases (Indiscernible) this year in response to public interest.
My jaw dropped when I read that.
What we have gotten from the OPA is not real transparency but a higher profile in response to a season of crisis and criticism.
Let's not pretend we have real transparency or real police accountability.
We need to start over with a fully civilian police oversight board that is elected by the people and accountable to them.
Go to Seattlestop.Org for more information.
The next Speaker is Andrew Carnahan.
Hello.
My name is Andrew Carnahan.
Can hear me?
We can.
I'm a licensed mental health counselor and substance abuse disorder professional.
I have been working in the city of Seattle for over 10 years.
During that time, I have served thousands of people, particularly around substance use disorder.
Of the thousands of people I worked with, exactly one of those people had a primary diagnosis of Psychedelic related substance use disorder.
I'm speaking in favor of the effort to Decriminalize nature and Decriminalize substances in the city of Seattle.
While look in my anecdotal experience, I have had a minimal amount of problems related to these substances.
And when we look at the literature on the topic, the substances have incredibly low profile for abuse or dependence and, when used responsibly, a really good safety record.

That coupled with the research on the medical efficacy of the substance, Furthermore we look at the facts that many spiritual traditions have a profound effect on their participants or the people in their conversation at reducing addiction and mental health disorders as well as the native American . You can see that clearly the harm done by these substances when balanced against the very likely benefit to individuals in the community as a whole, it makes no sense to keep the substances Criminalized.
I'm not just speaking about the medical use of these substances but particularly about their spiritual use in the studies have found the spiritual use and the use of these substances --
Thank you.

But Dominic is showing not present.
We will come back to him if that changes.
The next person we have showing as present is Ken Connolly.
And then we have two other people showing up not present.
Bob Johnson and George Soto.
If we get to the end of the next comments and neither Dominic Davis, Ben Johnson or George Soto are showing is not present, we will conclude the public comment.
My name is Ken Connolly and I reside at district 1. I am a mere carpenter.
I'm taking time away from my day to use my voice here at City Council and advocacy of Decriminalize Seattle and what they will calm with your help.
We all know the war on drugs is an incompetent or marginalized community.
Determination is a gather grow philosophy.
We all can agree that the government shouldn't tell anyone what they can or can't grow.
Psychedelics have helped me in more ways then I can ever imagine.
And I want that for everybody.
As research continues, the therapeutic benefits become more and more obvious.
The therapist you will hear from will agree.
Unfortunately, if it was not for this movement, I would have never spoken with or could I afford to speak with these brilliant minds.
Retirement, providing for a family and space travel are all legal but they all seem equally as unobtainable to me and many of my peers.
We see how this is working out in Oregon.
Keeping this in a strictly medical realm will Snuff regular Hard-Working people like me from all the benefits associated with Psychedelics.
Discontinuing a vicious cycle.
Bondage of consciousness is not a good look.
As far as Psychedelics go, I agree with (Indiscernible) and I give my time.
I see the last Republic Commenters are showing is not present.
With that, we will conclude public comment.
Thank you for joining us today.
And we move on to the item on today's agenda.
And we have the office of accountability before the committee present the 2020 annual report.
As mentioned earlier, police accountability is one of three bodies responsible for accountability and Seattle.
And investigating reports of misconduct.
Thank you for joining us today.
I appreciate your flexibility on scheduling.
In addition to the presentation, I would appreciate if you could also provide, at any point during the presentation does provide an update on the investigation on the six officers in D.C.
January 6th, the Timeline for completing the investigation.
And I think it is top of mind for a lot of folks, the description of the work that the OPA did on the pink umbrella case would be helpful.
At this point, I will turn it over to our Presenters today and ask that the Presenters from the office of police accountability introduce yourselves for the viewing public.
Really quick, I'm going to read the item into the record.
Agenda item number one, office of police accountability 2020 annual report.
Good morning.
I'm Andrew Myerberg from the office of police account ability.
I am the director.
Good morning.
My name is Anne Bettesworth.
And the assistant director of public affairs and policy at the office of police accountability.
Good morning.
I'm Lauren Caputo.
And the date and policy analyst at OPA.
Thank you so much, all of you, for joining us.
And with that, let's just dig right in and proceed with the presentation.
I will lead us off.
Like everyone on the Council, I appreciate, council member Herbold, your words this morning.
I think we were all horrified by what we saw last spring and into the summer.
And I think the Councilmember does the points Councilmember Sawant makes, I'm happy to answer any questions that you feel are necessary to answer.

I think what we will talk about today is that we worked incredibly hard and it our best with a very difficult year to try to move our system forward, whether through our investigations, their policy recommendations to try to modify and alter management policies or work with the legislative session through the spring and into the summer.
But today, what we want to do is talk about the whole of our work product and answer whatever questions we can.
Without further Ado, I will turn it over to Lauren to start.
To be have the presentation that we can display on the screen?
That would be ideal if you could do that.
I'm sorry.
I thought Council was showing the presentation?
But we can pull it up here if we need to.
Alex.
That would be great.
Usually the folks presenting sort of run the show.
Because you know the cadence of the presentation.
My Apologiesif we did not make that clear.
That was not clear.
Lauren, can you pull that up?
Do you mind doing it?
I'm looking for it.
It is attached to our agenda.
Okay, one moment.
Is that showing on the screen?
It is not.
Okay.
One moment.
While we load this up, I will give a quick overview of where we are.
Thank you.
So we have been giving periodic updates at the CDC and labeling where we are right now.
We have interviewed all six of the involved officers.
After the interviews occurred, we went to the supervisors and to Washington D.C. to do further analysis and investigation . We are trying to pull records.
For example, hotel records and video and other evidence that would be relevant to the case.
We are now in the process of Re- interviewing at least five of the six or potentially all six officers prior to issuing the findings.
Right now the findings are due in early July.
And we are on target to getting that done.

And I think it might be a good Segue to address the issue that Councilmember Sawant raised about how your office deals with the Timelines when the investigation is butting up against the 180 days and sort of the track record at getting those Timelines extended as needed.
I'm not sure I totally understand the initial question.
I'm not sure--so a Six- month disciplinary Timeline.
Unless there are some unique facts.
If we don't know the officer's name.
Obviously there are no Timelines and it only starts moving for a member of the bargaining unit and if an officer is an unidentified member of a bargaining unit.
Unless we seek an extension for example, if someone is on leave, or the case is pending investigation, all cases have to be done within six months.
With regard to the protest cases, we will move into the report.
We had about 145 cases roughly that stemmed from 19,000 complaints.
These complaints came in.
A lot of them came in the very beginning of the protest but they lasted through the fall and into the spring.
We periodically still get demonstration cases.
But usually they are one offs as opposed to five, six, seven or eight from one day.
Each of the cases is governed by a 180 daytime Lane.
In regards to the ones that are already occurred where the named employee was known, unless there was some Tolling, those cases are completed.
So findings have been issued and the Timeline is completed.
And so the cases are not outstanding.
I'm not exactly sure what the question was.
But anything that is still pending the 180 day Timeline is still an open investigation and we expect with 99% of the other investigations, that all cases will be done within the Timeline.
Thank you so much.
Let's move into the presentation.
All right.
If we can go to the first slide please.
We will start with the employees that received complaints.
40% of sworn officer employees received a complaint last year.
This graph here is showing both sworn and civilian employees.
With those two together, it is about 30% of all Seattle police Department employees received at least one complaint, which is pretty standard in 2019.
Wheels reported 30% of all SP employees received a complaint.
And the majority of them just received one complaint.
There were five officers he received seven or more complaints in 2020.
I requested that Andrew Myerberg do some analysis on the number or the percentage of officers who have voluntarily left the Department over the last year.
A percentage of those officers who also had pending complaints.

And I believe director Myerberg, you found that anything 20% -30% of 200 or so officers, at the point of Urinalysis had momentarily left the department had received a complaint over the last--during the period of sustained protests.
So basically, what I think the purpose of your question was, was to figure out if there is a correlation between Úofficers leaving and having complaints.
Were officers trying to leave SPD with pending complaints in order to avoid discipline?
And what we found was that while some officers had complaints, the rate of complaints was overall lower than the remaining officers.
So I don't think that proves the .1 way or the other but it doesn't necessarily create an inference.
Correct.
But can you confirm that it was 20-30% of officers?
Yes.
And that was officers that left and it was the first 200 or so officers that left?
We had run it to the time where you made the request which I think was about a month ago.
Thank you so much.
Perfect.
So the most common allegations received were professionalism, use of force and bias free policing.
These were the same top three we showed in recent years although slightly Reordered.
Use of force moved up.
And OPA logged at 58% increase in total allegations received.
And if he moved to the next slide, we will get a little deeper into this.
So each of these four allegations increased significantly regarding the SPD response to the protest.
As I mentioned, use of force increased significantly.
It was up 170% from 2019.
Also a pretty significant increase in supervisory responsibility.
That is because a lot of the responsibility in crowd management FALLS in the chain of command with supervisors and commanders.
Equipment and uniform allegations in a lot of cases related to the morning badges of the black tape covering the officer badge numbers initially.
And then later on, mask wearing complaints also stemming from protests.
So of course De-Escalation increased and that is kind related to use of force and often analyzed together.
So questions about slides four and five.

Wonering if you can give us some examples of professionalism complaints and then for the top three categories, do you have a sense of how many of the complaints are from the public compared to complaints from within the Department itself?
And I ask because another slide notes that 64% of the complaints were from the public during 2020 and 36% were from within SPD.
So interested to know what that looks like for the top three categories of complaints.
Are there categories that are more likely to report--to be reported by the Department?
Or by the public?
And then Finally, supervisory responsibility complaints went up significantly.
What kind of allegations does this type of a complaint detail?
I can start with the internal versus external complaints coming from the public.
We will get to that and a couple of slides.
Generally we analyze that on a case level basis where you can have multiple allegations within a case.
And so we will talk about community member filed Complaits in a couple of slides.
Andrew, do you have any examples?
Sure.
What I would say about allegations--generally, a community member, even an officer is not actually defining one of these categories of allegations that we use.
They will say,--we shouldn't have.
We are analyzing the case and saying, that is excessive use of force and it was De- escalation and it was crowd management.
You didn't use your--privilege really . I think this is something confusing at times.
Each case includes one or more allegations.
Generally, many more.
Usually case has between 2-6, or 7 allegations.
So a good example of force would be either under title eight which is the general use of force policy or title 14 which governs the use of force and will be the use of 40 Millimeters glass balls.
That is much of the force we are seeing in the protest context.
We are also seeing pushes or other types of force during the course of an arrest that would fall more under the general use of force policy which is 8.200.
Thank you.
Regardless of who defines the complaint, I am--and if it is covered later, that is fine.

But for the top three complaints--professionalism, forced use and bias free policing, I'm interested to know what percentage of those complaints, once designated or categorized by the OPA, what percentage came from the public and with what percentage came from within the Department.
And yes, I would love some examples of professionalism, allegations and responsibility allegations.
Lauren will cover your first question later on in a couple of slides.
With regards to the second question, professionalism is generally--there are two ways that we look at professionalism.
It could be the use of profanity, derogatory or contentious comments to individual.
So cases where people may be made a statement over radio or that were captured when they were assigned to protests that were deemed to be profanity or derogatory and resulted in sustained findings.
Professionalism also can be more broad and conduct that undermines public trust in the Department.
For example,--and this is not the protest context but you have a case where you used a department Database to look up information about your neighbor.
That would be profanity or something along those lines.
But it would be conduct that is improper and it undermines trust and confidence in yourself and in the Department.
That is generally professionalism.

Supervisory responsibility is basically supervisors in most cases making the decision to disperse crowds in the decision to authorize officers to use less lethal tools including blast balls, 40 Millimeters.
So in the protest context, it is unlike a normal patrol interaction where an officer is making that unilateral individual decision to use force.
Here, there is supervisory approval and authority provided to officers.
So we focus very much on the supervisors.
And I think almost everyone in the big picture involved the dispersal and involved a named employee who was a supervisor.

And the tricky thing and this is something we have discussed with Councilmember Herbold, that we are required to interview those individuals and investigate those individuals Ith our supervisors and we only have two of them.
Certainly that was a big workload issue for us.
That is an example of a supervisory responsibility.

So just wondering, I think the report notes that the growing number of complaints classified for investigation are from the community and in part, due to the Unsubstantiated Misconducts screening program that director Myerberg, you have initiated.
The report says in 2020, the supervisors screen 187 allegations of misconduct with the OPA director.
Úand requested referral in 90% of cases.
The rest are investigated and documented in the field by the chain of command rather than referred to by the aye complaints.

Want to highlight the office of the inspector general in the next quarterly audit of the OPA's determination of these incidents--we want to give you the opportunity, director Myerberg, to speak to your effort to spearhead this program and how you believe it is working.
To your first point, I think you are correct that--backing up for second, this is the number of investigations that come from complaints.
So the number--the percentage of complaints classified for investigations.

I will say that you are right and that the number of internal referrals that we receive, the percentage has gone down because normally, let's say it was 150 potentially, they would have come through our office and they would have been investigated.

So the purpose of the program was to take cases--and we saw this a lot early on in 2017 and 2018, to take cases that could be clearly refuted and we had allegations where someone said, you broke my back or my legs and I can't walk and the Video shows them walking and no force was used or allegations of sexual assault that occurred in patrol videos and the in car Video shows it did not occur.

The program purpose was to streamline the reviews of that type of misconduct and to allow supervisors to firmly disprove it, and propose how they want to handle the case with OPA and we would do our own review by looking at the Video and obviously Osu would audit it.
The program started as a pilot in 2018 and then expanded and then was approved by the court and the DOJ team and expanded over time.

So generally, what it does is it allows OPA to focus its resources on the cases that are not easily Describable by Video and then ensures that the chain of command is taking more responsibility and then providing that information to OPA.
Thank you.

Actually, a lot of those complaints, the tricky part about those complaints is some of those cases were handled as contact logs previously where they which is clearly so I don't know whether we have assessed that to say whether the rate would go up or down.
Certainly we--this rate has been consistent over time.

But I don't know that we have already answered that Councilmember.

68 employees were disciplined following OPA investigations in 2020.
Four employees were disciplined and more than one case each.
The most common discipline--and again this is showing the most common discipline reaction is a written Reprimand followed by a suspension and then Reprimand . to the next slide.
So disciplinary appeals dropped 70% from 2019.
There were eight appeals filed in 2020. two through the public safety civil service Commission and six went through the arbitration route of appeal.
Those of the two types of Appeals that officers can do.
And OPA now has data on appeals on our Website for the public to view and Download.
It is in our case data page on our Website and we updated that of a new appeal being filed or closed.
Obviously this is a big drop.
We have ideas as to what may have caused this but not a definitive answer.
So it will be a ton of different reasons why this drop occurred.
If you look at comparing this year, 2020, to 2019, we had more investigations and a similar sustained rate.
So more sustained cases.
So there were more sustained cases to be appealed.
But they were not appealed.
We sustained more use of force allegations in 2020 then we did in 2019.
Generally, those are the types of allegations that are appealed by the Union.
But almost all of them are not appealed.
So it could be that the Union was more judicious about what they brought to appeal.
It could be that they felt they didn't have the grounds to appeal the decisions issued.
It is very difficult to say why this drop occurred.
But it is a very significant drop.
And moving forward, I'm wondering if you can speak to how the resolution--of course we can't account the findings of this case for 2020 because it is relatively recent.
But for the viewing public, a look at the potential impact of the Adlai Shepard case on appeals moving forward and how that affects the ability of the argument for appeals.
I think that would be really useful.

I think is most people know, the Shepard case which involves the punching in the back of a patrol vehicle resulted in Mr. Sheppard's termination and an Arbitrator upheld the sustained finding but reverse the determination and opposed a disciplinary penalty but brought Mr.

Shepherd back in the city appealed and the court agreed and then it went to a higher court and fundamental, to your question, Councilmember Herbold, is the appellate court upheld the Superior Court and said that in recognizing this for the first time, a public policy and ensuring excessive force is not used.
And I think that we view this as an incredibly significant--many of the cases pending appeal are use of force cases.
Early on at OPA, I sustained a finding in an officer involved shooting in October of 2017 and both officers were terminated.
That case is up for appeal and we expect it will be one of the next appealed.

I think the city is in a stronger position today, given that ruling, insofar as thinking it provides more deference to the determination of the Department that the Terminations and sustained findings were issued in furtherance of the strong public policy towards excessive force.
Obviously, we will see how this is applied by Arbitrators moving forward.
I think we view it as very favorable for the city, particularly in the context of excessive force cases.
I'm going to take over Non- talk about the OPA protest data and response.
Starting in late May and throughout the rest of the year, they calculated the number of times we have been contacted about police contact and conduct.
It is over 19,000 and probably closer to 20,000 contacts they received.
And a lot of these were about similar incidents, about 13,000 I believe were about the child pepper spray incident.
So what we did was sort through these and determine which ones needed to be investigated and that resulted in about 145 incidents that required investigation.
So that is the number of investigations we have right now.
That is the 145 number.
And of those, 99%--or 99 total have been completed or shown on the Website.

Those have been extended for a couple different circumstances including based on Covid-19 and other Timeline necessities.
Of the 99 pieces completed, 18 contained sustained findings.
So often there are multiple obligations within a case and so of those, 18 of the cases, there are sustained findings in them.
The also--the OPA has the ability to make systemic policy recommendations.
This is an option for director Myerberg when he feels like the individual did not commit misconduct.
It was more of a deficiency in the policy for the training being the issue.
So we made systemic policy recommendations in 12 unique cases.
Those range from policy recommendations about blast balls, to providing medical aid . There is a range of those.
Those are all shown on the Website as well.
Councilmember Morales has a question.
Okay.
Thank you so much.
If we can quickly come on the slide, you mentioned that of the 19,000, about 13,000 were related to that one incident with the child.
Any talk about what the other 6000 was and how this got to 145 that resulted in investigations?
There were tons of different incidents.
We sorted through and try to figure out which ones were talking about the same incidents.
And initiated investigations into those.
We go through and list every individual case on our Website.
We created a protest on the dashboard and we talked about summarizing each individual case on there and talk about the progress and where it is in the process.
To add a little more detail, to your point, Councilmember Morales, the one we focused on when we talked about numbers was the child pepper spray case and that was 13,000.
There were several other complaints that occurred early in the protest that did go viral, that we received a number of complaints on.
We probably could do--it is a little difficult just because of the massive amount of information.

And so we were able to--some of them for example, contain the language and it was the same exact type of complaint.
We were able to De- Dupe and go through the different contacts again one by one by one and come up with 145 unique cases.
Where there was a question, we deferred to creating a unique case and did not just lump things together because they were connected.
We were careful to create as many unique cases as we deemed appropriate.
Does that answer your question?
It would be helpful to get a sense of the other complaints, or other actions that drew large numbers of complaints.
I imagine the pink umbrella case is one such case.
I imagine the punching in the face of the Protester on the ground is another such case.
I think it would be helpful to get a sense of that big picture and follow-up afterwards.
I think is fair to say you are correct.
Post the case with the officer that put a knee on somebody's neck.
The vast majority of complaints are received just by percentage or basically from the first day of the protest until June 1ST.
That was the vast majority of cases and complaints we received.
We continue to receive them periodically.
That was the massive amount that came in.
Thank you.
Straight from the get go, in May, we recognized a need to increase transparency.
There was a lot of public interest around the protests and how OPA would respond to them.
So we put our heads together and came up with a few different ways that we could give the public more information.
We created a public Dashboad that shows progress for the protest cases.
It has Doughnuts for each case similar to what you are seeing on the screen.
And we created a list showing each of the 10 steps in the investigation process just probably.
And it shows, for each of these cases, what step OPA investigators are on for that case.

Every three weeks--and it used to be more frequently, but now we are at every three weeks, we roll out a new batch of cases that we--so we can roll them out on one day and show the public at once instead of trickling them out.
And we put out a Tweet on social media, often to a press release.
And Dr. nay for does media interviews to give additional information.

Sometimes we have videos we started doing that seem to be very helpful for the public where we have someone on our staff go through and pull pieces of the videos that help to explain the findings that director Myerberg has come to the conclusion about the case.
All the Video clips are put together.
It is a mix of body worn Video or third-party Video.
And we either do a Voiceover narration or have text on the screen.
It is just a much more simple way for the public to see what the findings are rather than reading, for example, a 10 page document that lays it out in detail.
So those were a few ways that we expanded our public presence in trying to give more information on where we were at and why we were doing what we were doing.
And relating to the systematic policy recommendations, I know that each report from OPA includes that information when appropriate.

But am wondering, if it is pulled out as well, I know the CPC has, the community police Commission, created a dashboard of its recommendations and tracking which ones are implement it and which ones are not.
Wondering if the OPA has already done something like that.
I believe you have but just checking.

We have a page on our Website under the policy tab that lists each management action that we have issued and it has a link to the actual letter that we send to the police Department and summarizes the case and the recommendation and lists the status, whether it has been active or partially implemented or fully implemented.
And we link, on that same status, we link documentation that the police Department sends back to us where they describe what they did to put that recommendation into action.
Does your report have a findings around those recommendations?
A number of policy recommendations made, the number that SPD has, either in progress or has already taken?
This particular annual report does not give a breakdown of the number implemented versus not.
We do list in an Appendix, every recommendation made.

Because the SPD resources were so slim based on staffing and protests and a lot of attrition, they weren't able to address a lot of the recommendations issued in 2020 because they were so late in the year.
So it didn't feel like a fair statistic to put in the report that we had issued all of these in the last month of the year but they hadn't implemented them.
It takes quite a bit of time to make the policy change.
Understand.
Thank you.
I think we did know where something was declined and I want to say there was only one declined action which means we received a but we are not going to take further action.
Most of them have either been implemented or are active evaluations by a speedy.
So in 2020, OPA conducted a lot of state legislative work.
This was the first for our office.
We conducted--we got a team of staff when all the Protester happening.
There were so many various recommendations from sources in the community, from city Council, from legislators.

We wanted to, and House, take a look at a lot of these recommendations and evaluate how they could be implemented and what kind of research was behind them and what was done in other areas for example.
So we started evaluating these recommendations.

We put them all on a spreadsheet and looked at about 52 recommendations and from there, we drafted papers and did a bunch of research and Crafted papers for ourselves to just educate ourselves so we could talk more and talk about this with legislators and Councilmembers about it on 23 of these topics.
And from there, from those 23, we developed seven proposals to highlight for the state Legislature.
The seven proposals were the things that OPA felt would be the most effective to implement at the state level.
So these seven, I will run over them very quickly.
The first was reforming collective bargaining.
The second was improving the officer decertification process.
The third was creating an independent special Prosecutor to make charging decisions.
The fourth was creating an office to conduct independent Investiations into deadly force by police.
The fifth was reforming objective Reasonableness.
The sixth was creating a statewide use of force Database.
The seventh was to create statewide De-Escalation policies.
We transmitted those one Pagers to state legislators.
We participated in committee hearings and gave testimony.
We engaged in direct meetings to provide facts and answer questions from legislators.
And we had a staff member that participated in the governor task force on independent investigations of police use of force.
We definitely had a strategy and engagement that we stepped up with for this session of state legislator.
And a question on the seven priorities.

For the seven priorities, which of them--I think the question I would have is really focused on improving Seattle's own police accountability system . and how many are in support of the efforts statewide, which of course are very important.
And is a leader here in Seattle, we want to share the work that we have done in approving the statewide system.
For instance, the statewide De- escalation policies and the statewide use of force Database and mandatory reporting.
Just wondering how those items would impact Seattle conducting office to conduct independent investigations into deadly force by police.
Just trying to get a sense of how many of these were really focused on needed Seattle improvements versus the necessary improvement of police accountability statewide.
I can jump in their.
I would say it is both.
I think most of them would impact Seattle fairly significantly.
For example, putting in place a reform for the objective Reasonableness standard.

One thing I discussed--I disgusted in front of the committee at the Senate side or the House side, that the OPA decision--and this is something not well understood but the OPA decisions are based on the application of a Reasonableness standard.
So we are required under case law to look at, what would a reasonable officer D█O when the officer is placed with the same training experience and not applying 2020 hindsight.
It is an extremely Deferential standard for police officers.

One of the things we talked to the Legislature about was, are there reforms you can make to that standard, to make it less Deferential and more in line with any changing expectations around police force.
Ultimately, they did not make changes at the state level to the Reasonableness standard.
What they did do and we were very supportive of this, is they did create a baseline policy for both De-Escalation and use of force that would be applied statewide, which we thought was great.
We were very supportive of it.
We worked with those legislators to develop the.
For example, the statewide entity that would look at all deadly force--right now, SPD is under consent decree but absent is the legislation when it comes to the consent degree lifted.
Is pretty would have been investigate a by a task force of officers from other jurisdictions.
We pushed for years.
And this is not just okay but it is Oig and the Seattle deadly force investigation cap task force that was convened a couple years ago pushing for exactly this.
To have an independent civilian blood, civilian staffed entity that investigates deadly use of force statewide.
So this is a huge accomplishment.
It is something we were very supportive of and very much mirrored what our liquidations were in our proposal.
The Database is something we feel very strongly about and feels very important.
We did not get the special prosecutor.
This is another thing that OPA feels is very important.

The charging decision should be with someone totally independent of political pressure and someone that can make a decision without worrying about working with the same officers the next day or the next month.
And not that we are doubting the ability of elected prosecutors to do so but it puts another layer of accountability and transparency to have a special prosecutor.
So these are all things that will probably be a future.
For example, collective bargaining.
One thing we discussed was the possibility of putting in and creating a law that would say that accountability bargaining is affects only.
So you wouldn't Bargainable Mentation but just the effects of the bargaining.
There are changes that still need to be done for arbitration.
There are a lot of things out there that we cannot do at the city level necessarily but that greatly impact city work.

Exactly why I asked the question, you and I both often say that we are hampered by the consent decree and making changes to our current system because any changes we would make would have to be approved by the court.

And we are also limited in our ability to make changes because of our current contract with Spog so I'm interested in the changes that would, in Realtime, make improvements to the Seattle current system that we were successful in making progress at with the state level.

And also really appreciating the advocacy that is really important to do with our partners all over the state, including police accountability advocates for statewide reforms which may not directly impact Seattle.
So really appreciate the detail they are.
I would also say the decertification bill also is an extremely important bill that has come out and there was a lot of work by Seattle partners on that bill.
We worked very closely with Senator Peterson Pedersen's office.
There was a lot of work that went into it.
And this is very much a change in police accountability too that it can now investigate use of force.
Is another check on local jurisdiction that don't have any independent internal affairs.
Because Seattle, for all the criticisms of our system, as far as I'm aware, we are the only internal affairs system across the state that is civilian led and civilian staff.
So again, empowering the Cjtc to take more affirmative action and make sure officers don't get employed again is another big change occurring within the system.
So we were very happy with the result.
Obviously we did not get everything we supported past and we excited that.
But the progress made this last legislative session was immense.
Thank you.
I will talk briefly about staff being this past year.
This is the current organizational chart.
This is actually the 2020 organization.
It is the 2020 chart.
As you can see, we fully civilian eyes the two open civilian spots . and we are still I believe it eight sworn two civilian investigators.
We expect the--I'm sorry, nine and two.
Again, that is a function of the contract.

And I think people always say that you should civilian eyes half of your staff and we don't have the ability to do that--since the first contract was passed, we civilian eyes all the investigation supervisors, the two lieutenants and captain and have added those civilian investigators.
Our expectation and they were agreed upon by all the parties and will move forward accordingly.

A couple future and state issues for 2021. one thing mentioned earlier about transparency is one thing we found very effective which was the creation of videos and putting up videos that explain not just what occurred but showing the multiple angles and going to the conclusions and why we reach those conclusions.

My hope in 2021 is to bring on a full-time Video analyst that will have that be there Full- time job and they will be responsible for creating a Video Ideally for every single sustained and Nonsustained case that will explain the findings.
That can be provided both to the complainant and can be linked to the closed case summary when it goes Online.
It is putting more information out there and having people, even if they disagree, understand how we decide what we decided and how we got to where we got.
We are also, as we talked about, very focused on data and Dashboards.
One thing we are working on for example, we rolled out the appeals dashboard and the physicians of those appeals.
W will work on putting together a dashboard given some of the public concern with the chief's reversal of the--case.

A dashboard that talks about every case that has been reversed based on the chain of command disagree with OPA and links all the relevant documents so people can see for themselves what the rationale was and what the reversal was and what the result of it was.

For example, with the pink umbrella case, that would include linking like you said Councilmember Herbold about Councilmember Lewis as well as correspondence from the chief and the underlying decision and a letter disagreeing and any discipline eventually imposed.
Having this information all in one place, it seems like a small thing but I think with information comes power.
So as much information we can put out there is super important for Moore perspective.
Thank you.
For the investigative unit, could you, just for the viewing public,--tell us, what is the limiting language of the contract.
Specifically.
Is it specifically civilian investigators are allowed?
So the specific language that OPA can hire up to two civilian investigators.
He gave us a specific number.

If you are accountability ordinance from 2017 did not have a specific number but basically what it said was, it should be in the OPA director discretion to decide what the staffing arrangement will be.
Certainly the monitor--before he left was a very strong supporter with a 50/50 split of civilian versus investigators.
I'm not sure at this point if there are questions about what we discussed or questions about certain cases.

I'm happy to walk to that finding.
