If that would be helpful.

And I'm happy to talk about some of the recommendations we have made specifically around demonstration management, some of the things we have pushed for and what we have seen as far as changes in tactics and what we expect the tactics to look like like if protests occur again this summer.
It is really up to the Council, as to what we answer, if anything.
I see Councilmember Morales' hand is up.
Sorry.
I will lower it.
I think would be helpful to--address, you are on record around the child pepper spray case.
For the viewing public that may have missed it, going over the investigation and the findings, it would be useful.
I do have a question related to, back on slide three for employees with seven, nine, 11 and 14 complaints.

And I'm just wondering, on that one, when you will know how many, if any, of the complaints will be sustained against officers with a large number of allegations, and whether or not we reported out that way so that the other components of the police accountability system, the Oig and the CPC as well as the general public,--I understand there is a requirement to not be involved with the identity of the officer complaints against them even when sustained.
And we know for those particular officers that have a lot of complaints against them, how many of those complaints were sustained.
And absolutely.
Talking to some of the policy changes that were made because of your work, especially in the area of changes that the Department has made around crowd control weapons.
I'm sorry, crowd control, I should say.
And how that was in response to feedback received by SPD from the OPA would be useful as well.
And also, opening up to the questions of other Councilmembers here as well.
I will start with the first question.
The complaint of the child pepper spray case came from the Video taken in the aftermath of the pepper spray occurring where the child was in the middle of the street and was crying.
What we did was we went backwards.
We worked to isolate where the child was in the crowd.
Because that part of the Video was taken after the fact and did not show the use of force itself.
We were able to isolate where the pepper spraying occurred.
As you all may recall, initially, an officer was identified by name as being the opposite of that used the pepper spray.
And we determined pretty quickly that that was not the officer that had done so.
But we were able to identify who did.
Looking at the Video and looking at the body worn Video between 8-10 officers on the line, what we were able to see is that at some point, they made an arrest at the Right- hand side of the line.
It was an individual that had thrown pepper spray at an officer earlier and then had drawn the pepper spray bottle at the officer.
That was discussed at another complaint.
We evaluated and saw that that individual that was identified as doing that was arrested at the right side of the line.
When they did this, the officers moved out to push the line back to allow a buffer to make the arrest.
What happened was that people convened into the line and started Pushinginto the officers.
At that moment, a male with the Úchild was viewed quickly walking toward the line and going toward where the conflict was occurring.
The officer at that point deployed pepper spray at a woman who was actively grabbing another officer's baton.
That woman turned and ducked at the time and the pepper spray went off of her shoulder and struck the father and the kid who were standing directly behind that woman.
So when we evaluated the deployment of pepper spray, what we looked at was first of all, was the pepper spray of the woman pushing to the line and grabbing the baton, was it justified?
From my perspective, the answer is yes.
The woman was pushing through the line and was grabbing on to the officer's baton.
They had other people pushing through the line and it was a chaotic situation.
They are entitled as a matter of law to move the crowd back and prevent her from doing so.
The officers asked when they had a couple of options available.
The use of a glass ball which would have been an appropriate.
They could have gone hands-on and pulled the woman down or pushed her away or used some force or they could have deployed pepper spray.
They felt that pepper spray directed toward this person was the best option for the circumstances and I agree.

The question then was, was it a foreseeable result that the pepper stray, that the woman would dock and the pepper spray would bounce off of her back and hit the father and the child who had moved behind them?
From my perspective, the answer was no.
It was not a foreseeable result of that use of force that targeted the female.
So this was a decision that obviously was a difficult decision to reach.
There was a lot of criticism regarding the decision, which I except.
The reality is, no matter what I say about this, I have described my findings on this multiple times.
No matter there will be people that disagree with the findings and that is totally acceptable.
You can disagree with me and say I'm wrong and that's fine.
Looking at the policies in place at the time and looking at the conduct and looking at the Video and Accessing the interviews, that is the finding we reached.
What it will say is that, I think is correct to say that that case in and of itself did not result in a change of policy surrounding pepper spray.
And I think it is accurate to say that I did not support the Council's initial bill that would have put a ban on all devices.
That was the initial Iteration that was changed over time.

I'm significantly more supportive of the bill that exists now that I think is much more targeted and understands that while we never went anything like that to be used in a protest, there may be times it is required.
So there is a balance.
So Councilmember support with Sawant--I don't support all the tools but I don't think is realistic.
I do support in one of the changes and liquidations made over the last couple of cases is, more and more, I tend to support a blanket ban on blast balls for example.
I'm very concerned with blast balls and the fact that even if you deploy a Bast blast ball perfectly, it can move 10 feet in another direction and shrapnel can come off and affect other people.
I think what we have scene is that using a blast ball to move crowds should not be done and the blast ball, if ever used, should be to target a specific and direct threat.
But again, I don't like blast balls.
They are the least targeted of tools that is.
Officers have at their disposal.
I think that it is inaccurate to say that we haven't pushed for changes to both the law and policy.
We have.
And many of the changes as PD has put into place--for example, they will not use blast balls simply to move crowds.
They are required to point to specific identifiable threat of harm when you will be using the blast balls on people.
And these are the results of the cases we have investigated in liquidations we have made along with the work our partners have done in the CDC and the Oig.
So other tactical changes that have gone into place.

One thing we really pushed for and this was a result of the report Councilmember Herbold asked us to issue early on, is we had pushed for, if the protests are about SPD to stop interacting directly with protesters, one of the big tactical mistakes that SPD was engaged in--and this isn't rocket science.
Spd has admitted this and has confirmed this, it is creating artificial lines in trying to move crowds when it was unnecessary.
Again, there is always a balance between preventing property destruction and harm to people.
But interfering with protests and not allowing people to walk to the city and make their voices heard.
I think what they would do differently this summer is they will not be creating lines like we saw at the East precinct.
They will not be trying to dictate where everybody is moving at any given time.
I think they will stage and respond to life safety issues and intervene with specific acts of criminality.
Other than that, they will let Úpeople exercise their first amendment rights without causing conflict.
I think this goes to De- escalation and reducing harm and increasing public trust and confidence.
And at the end of the day, I applaud SPD for modifying the tactic and doing so in response to what they heard both from the Council and from the accountability entities.

Other things that were put into place as we push for better communication with the Oig, a lot of what we saw early on is that people, for example, if you have 5000 people of the crowd, it is possible people in the back and I hear the dispersal order.
And for people concerned, it cannot be used as an acoustic weapon.
It is only an amplifier.
So that is used to amplify warnings.
And you can hear from all areas of the crowd what was being announced.
And you know what dangers may be present.
And this can be communicated better with the protesters that should yield better outcomes.

We are anticipating and we are excited to see the results of the Oig review which we expect will have even more systemic recommendations with more of a community lens we have a very systematic system lens.

And we think that they will be talking more about communication and even having people specifically geared to communicate within crowds and coordinate with people to coordinate goals and tactics and decisions by the police Department and try to build communication and cooperation with them.
We expect a very different response to these protests and what we saw last spring and into the summer.
And we have been to the training.
We have seen Rollouts of the tactics.
This isn't just conjecture.
This is what I have seen.
And we will be holding SPD accountable to the new standards.
And again, we expect to see positive changes.
Lauren, there was another question I skipped over.
It was about the number of complaints against certain individuals.
I don't know if you want to talk about the.
I would Guesstimate that some of those are supervisors who were named in multiple complaints for the ones that had seven or 11 --
A lot of them were heavily involved in the protest response last year.
I remember when we presented last year, the annual report, at the end of it, you asked for a similar set of data.
I can run that data on those officers who received seven or more complaints and they give you the outcome of that.
And we don't identify the officers by name.
And we wouldn't report specifically on those cases because it involves the officers not identified.
And I would guess that some of those would be supervisors in charge of multiple protest responses.
Higher up the chain of command.
Correct.
Thank you.
I'm just wanting to make sure that my colleagues don't have any additional questions.
I have one additional protest complaint related question and then I want to move, shift over to use of force complaints from--related to individuals in behavioral and mental health crises.

So related to recommendations that you see as potentially coming out of your investigation of protests related complaints, I have noted that it might be useful to make changes to Seattle's bill of rights, and recognition both of the courage of observers like Darnell Frazier who used her rights to observe and record the murder of George Floyd, but it occurs to me that we have a law that is our own sort of codification of the rights of people to observe and record.
But it might be useful to make some changes to that law coming out of potential recommendations that you have from investigations that you have done.
I believe, director Myerberg, you have Referenced some changes you might like to see specifically related to the rights of the press.
I have noted that there were charges that officers obscured observers viewing of certain actions that they were taking in instances where the protesters were not--a distance it was unsafe to observe.
They were a safe distance away.
But yet it appeared that officers intentionally were blocking the view.
Just wondering whether or not you might have some additional recommendations for us to strengthen what I think is a really important law here in Seattle.
I have one recommendation that came out of the July 25th protest.

It was surrounding the increase of protections for both media and legal observers and creating designated areas, making sure that, unless absolutely necessary, that you are not dispersing those folks out of an area and they are not being subject to force.

The complicated factor is that there are times when media may be interspersed in demonstrations and may be in front of or in the midst of a demonstration and it would be very difficult, if for example, there was a life safety issue, it would be difficult to not affect the media.
Where the media is in an area off to the side, they need a vantage point.
And also they need to be mindful that there may be a law enforcement need to disperse the crowd.
It is creating that balance.
It is something we have asked the Department to further develop and its tactical plans action plans and policies.

I would say fundamental, mentioning people that have taken the role of recordings--I would also give credit to Lamar Saulsberry who is fundamental to our understanding of some of the things that went wrong in these protests.
For example, the June 1ST pink umbrella case.
That Video caught that firsthand and showed the experience of someone in the front of the line and was a huge piece of evidence that we relied upon.
For the ordinance you had championed, Councilmember Herbold, without evidence.
We feel like it is very important obviously and we have recommended changes.
And I can update the Council at a later point and we will update the Council to let you know what changes were put into place by SPD.
Thank you director Myerberg.

On the issue of use of force and Individuls and the behavior or mental health crisis, I just want to get a little bit of information specifically on--because I understand we are--this is a case that is--I don't know if it is bumping up against the deadline, but it it is of the death at the hands of police last year, I think it is the oldest one.
The Terry cave or case.
Just a little bit of a sense of what the Timeline is for your Dispositional not.
Another is a lot of interest in that.
It is a case that there is a lot of concern with, with the officers and the De-Escalation tactics used in that particular, unfortunate case.

And if you could speak a little bit to some of the recommendations that I know that you, the inspector general, judge and myself, have made to SPD around less lethal force tools that can be used in these types of cases.
I had the opportunity to participate with the CPC and other members of the community and the office of the inspector general was represented as well.
And on a demonstration of a new tool that the Department is considering piloting.
Maybe you can talk a little bit about that as well.
I want to be, as far as the shooting of Terry cave or, I want to be cognizant of the fact that while my investigation has been completed, it is still an open case.
I don't necessarily feel comfortable right now Commenting on this disposition until that has gone three for the resolution.

A big focus for that case and certainly for the shooting of Derek Hayden was looking at the tactics and decision-making of the officer and whether the failure to apply certain topics may have increased the likelihood that the high-level force would be used and that certainly is the fundamental question for those cases and those will likely be relevant to each other and to the determination that we reach.
And I think I will probably have an update in the next 30 days about what the final disposition is on that case.
That I can say that the OPA work is done and we are waiting for further proceedings.
As far as recommendations, one of the things we have seen from that case and from others--this is not new.
It is John tea Williams as well.
Please officers of people armed with knives and not all cases with knives are created equal.
Certainly the ones very concerning for us are the ones where you have the ability to put into place time, distance and shielding and you don't.
For example, the John Williams case, the officer was--multiple feet away from Mr.
Williams and where there were other steps he could have taken prior to firing his gun.
The consensus was that yes, there were.
And same with these other cases.

The problem is right now the only tool--if you get to the point where you need to use force, the only tool that makes a lot of sense in that scenario is a 40-Millimeter launcher which is--it shoots a round that can and give us to a person with a knife.
The issue with that is very few people are trained with a 40- millimeter.
And maybe a couple of people on the squad.
So not every officer is trained with a 40-Millimeter.
In some cases, if there is not a 40-Millimeter trained officer present and you don't have a 40- millimeter at the scene, it greatly limits the amount of standoff distance you can have.
One thing Councilmember Herbold had mentioned and that I actually had issued a reclamation to the Department to consider is, it has different terms but it is called basically a net gun.
What it would do is, it sounds kind of ridiculous.
What it would do is literally shoot a net.
It sounds--it should saying that that would go around an individual and prevent the individual from moving and because the individual to fall down to the ground.
I think we are very open to a lot of different possibilities.
I think SPD has gotten the approval to get one and maybe you saw the demonstration of it Councilmember Herbold.
We think that everything needs to be out there.
The other big gap is just training.
And training is everything.
Both from Academy, when you are taught that anyone with a knife represents a mortal threat to you no matter how far away they are.
Many police academies across the country teach this.
And also, the training you get internally.
Very few officers--SPD doesn't have this sort of a fluid and mobile training where you are outside and you are following someone down the street and all the sudden they turn toward you and run.
That is not trained in SPD.
We very much feel like it would make sense.
And we know the limitations for Covid-19 and for resources.
But to have an outdoor fluid training method puts officers into the scenarios they are going to face in real life and not just to rely on classroom training.

If you don't build up muscle memory and ability to contemplate the situations, what you then expect is you will put someone in a classroom and then out in the street and you are going to expect them to make a perfect decision.
It will happen in some cases but it won't happen in other cases.
And how you ensure you have good outcomes, I think it comes down to better policies, better tools and better training.
And that is really what we are Pusing for SPD.
And I think Oig is on the same page.
And SPD has been a very willing partner.
I think they understand there has been a gap.
This has been a nationwide gap.
I don't know any other jurisdiction that does this well.
It doesn't give a speedy an excuse but it means that SPD has the opportunity to innovate and create a better way.
And I think the vision from the chief, the articulated vision of the chief's we never have another shooting of a person with a knife.
Thank you so much, director Myerberg.
Those are all the questions that I have.

I appreciate your ongoing work and your recognition that our system of accountability is evolving and sometimes the criticisms that we receive about our system, that leads to ongoing and enhanced improvements to that system.
Councilmember, if I can add one note to the.
I would caution, all of us who think about those questions, it is to say, it is good to sometimes have perspective as to where we have, and where we are.
I think in 2017, when the systems were created, they were not created to say, this is all--we will never change the systems or get past the systems.
The reality is the systems created in 2017 were created based on extensive research.
I was part of the team working as the Council and attorney to work on the research and come up with, what are the models across the country and what Úexisted?
I think we were confident across the board that this was the best model that existed.
I think to this point, I don't know the model yet that I think is a better model than what we have with regards to our system of checks and balances and our Pre-Accountability entities.
It doesn't mean the system will be perfect.
What I think is that out of all the models that exist, we probably have the best.
Does that mean we don't try to change it?
No.
Of course it doesn't mean that.
I want to be careful with the changes we create because they should be based on evidence.
They should be based on research.
They should be based on changes that would be positive and not just coming up with a system that will have its own flaws and are systems we may be those--reasons why they were not adopted in 2017.
And so I caution to recognize that we have and the benefits and work Collaboratively to keep improving them so we will be willing partner.
You are muted.
Thank you director Myerberg.

On that same note, I want to recognize some of the words of Reverend Harriet Walden in a recent letter specifically focused on the need for ongoing and continued improvement on reduction of the use of force and with a specific focus on individuals and behavioral mental health crisis.

She wrote, in 2012, the city entered into a consent decree with the Department of justice that guaranteed an expansion of the program to reduce the use of force against individuals and Behaviorl or mental health crisis.
At that time, 70% of all use of force encounters between citizens and SPD officers involved people in a behavioral health crisis.
At this point, as of the last analysis, it was received in 2020, based on 2019 numbers.
But SPD has reduced the percentage to 23%.
Sold for only 3% of all use of force encounters Arnell against individuals and behavioral or mental health crisis.
She goes on to say that some of the 10,000 contacts the SPD officers have each year in people behavioral health crisis, only a fraction is any physical contact at all.

Recognizing that progress does not mean we cannot drive forward and address the issues that we are identifying as continued challenges and I think everybody recognizes that police contacts with armed, specifically armed individuals and behavioral health crisis continues to be a challenge for our city.
With that, took more of your time the normal perhaps for the annual report.
I think it is important to dig into your work on this one-year anniversary.
If there are no other comments or questions from my colleagues--and I see none.
The next public safety Committee is scheduled for June 8th.
Again, if there are no other comments from my colleagues, we are adjourned.
Thank you.
